title: 113_hr3382
content: The "Smarter Sentencing Act of 2013" clarifies the applicability of statutory minimums and the Fair Sentencing Act. It amends Section 3553(f)(1) of title 18, United States Code, to specify that the criminal history category for the defendant must not be higher than category 2. The "Smarter Sentencing Act of 2013" clarifies the applicability of statutory minimums and the Fair Sentencing Act by allowing reduced sentences for covered offenses committed before August 3, 2010. No motion to reduce a sentence can be entertained if it was previously imposed or reduced in accordance with the amendments made by sections 2. The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 allows for reduced sentences for certain offenses, but a court is not required to reduce a sentence under this act if a previous motion was denied. The Fair Sentencing Act of 2010 allows for reduced sentences for certain drug offenses, but a court is not required to reduce a sentence if a previous motion was denied. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to reduce minimum sentences for certain drug offenses. For example, the minimum term of imprisonment is changed from 20 years to 10 years for certain offenses. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to reduce minimum sentences for drug offenses. For example, the minimum term of imprisonment is changed from 20 years to 10 years for certain offenses. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to reduce minimum sentences for drug offenses, changing the minimum term of imprisonment from 20 years to 10 years for certain offenses. Directive to the Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines for drug offenses to decrease penalties in accordance with recent amendments to the Controlled Substances Act and the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act. The Commission must consider its mandate under section 994(g) of title 28. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to formulate sentencing guidelines to minimize Federal prison overcrowding, consider findings on mandatory minimum penalties, assess fiscal implications of guideline revisions, address public safety concerns, and ensure severe penalties for violent drug traffickers. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to promptly promulgate guidelines and make conforming amendments to reduce racial disparities in Federal sentencing, in accordance with emergency authority granted by the Act. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment detailing how the savings from reduced Federal corrections spending will be used to address prison overcrowding, enhance law enforcement, and reduce criminal recidivism.
